name: Memory Keepers and Future Seekers
description:
Attend the book launch of 'Memory Keepers and Future Seekers' by Ulka Chauhan and Samira Sheth. 

Featuring six heritage homes, this book explores themes of architecture, culture, heritage, anthropology, identity and belonging. It features photographs by Chauhan and text by Sheth and includes visual and literary portraits of Goa’s 300+ year old heritage homes, attempting to present their untold stories through a series of in-depth interviews with the home owners. A layered narrative, the book brings to light the stories of families and their fragments of memories while touching upon the historical, cultural, political, social and religious moments that shaped Goa. 

In conversation with architect Robert Stephens, the two authors discuss their process, insights from their experience of putting this book together, and the relevance of looking at heritage through multiple lenses; as much personal, as historical and monumental.

name: Artist Talk: Tarik Currimbhoy
description:
Join contemporary artist, designer and architect Tarik Currimbhoy for an intimate discussion on his practice and work.

Currimbhoy’s multi-faceted practice is marked by his mastery of juxtaposing the old and the new, creating sculptures that are modern and minimal in form. His design work has been widely recognised and published on a global scale, and his sculptures are prominently displayed in public spaces, as well as within corporate and private collections across the world. Often playing with tactility, his sculptures prompt a closer exploration with touch to feel the sensations of the materials. 

This is a unique opportunity to interact with a renowned contemporary artist and take a peek behind the curtain of his inspiration and process.

This event is conceptualised under our exhibition Painting with Fire: Jeram Patel & Tarik Currimbhoy

name: Guided Walk of Outside In (Kannada)
description:
The exhibition, Outside In: Meera Mukherjee and Jaidev Baghel, explores how these two artists pushed the boundaries of metal casting. Foregrounding their sculptures and the metal casting technique of Bastar Dhokra, this exhibition highlights an important moment in the history of modern art in India.

Join Rajesh K from the MAP team, as he takes you through the exhibition, detailing the labour-intensive process of metal casting and exploring how community-building was part of their practices.

This walkthrough will be conducted in Kannada

name: Artist Walk with Tarik Currimbhoy
description:
Experience a special walkthrough of the exhibition Painting with Fire led by one of the featured artists, Tarik Currimbhoy. In this session, get up close and personal with Tarik Currimbhoy’s vision, hear him discuss his inspirations and the process involved in creating his artworks.

Painting with Fire showcases 15 artworks by two artists, Jeram Patel and Tarik Currimbhoy, exploring two different styles using the same technique. The artworks invite you to explore the space through movement and shifting perspectives, and a theatrical play of colour.

This walkthrough is conceptualised under our exhibition Painting with Fire: Jeram Patel & Tarik Currimbhoy

name: 27 Down
description:
This weekend, travel back to the seventies and enjoy Awtar Krishna Kaul’s 27 Down, a 1974 drama based on the Hindi novel Athara Sooraj Ke Paudhe. The film is centred around Sanjay, a railway employee who is battling between his duty towards his authoritarian father and his desire for freedom. 27 Down is popular for its unique cinematography, themes of societal expectations, pursuit of dreams and self-discovery.

This film screening is the second in our six-month long series, ‘The Radical Seventies’, a collaboration between MAP and Bangalore Film Forum, co-curated by Ashish Rajadhyaksha. 

This series has been conceptualised as part of MAP’s youth engagement programming.

The Radical Seventies is a series that is specially crafted for youth to engage with older classics that resonate with our contemporary times, in familiar and unexpected ways. Through the 1970s, Indian cinema saw several major experiments in cinema — often made in direct conversation with radical politics. The decade began in the late 1960s and spilled over into the early 1980s. With 27 Down, we embark on another chapter of this journey, exploring questions around evolving identities, migration, and the push and pull between independence, empowering anonymity and the loneliness of the urban experience.
